Answer: Replaces us how? If it means taking over meaningless drudgery, that seems like a good thing overall. If it means taking over analysis of data and situations, that could be an improvement, if we could trust the judgement of the machines (for example self-driving cars). If it’s replacing artists and creative people, it’s just about creating a distinction between the human-made (and therefore sometimes quirky and imperfect) version and the inhumanly perfect and rapid machine made version. Hand-made crafts are already being presented today as a special valued category. All of these changes could eReplaces us how? If it means taking over meaningless drudgery, that seems like a good thing overall. If it means taking over analysis of data and situations, that could be an improvement, if we could trust the judgement of the machines (for example self-driving cars). If it’s replacing artists and creative people, it’s just about creating a distinction between the human-made (and therefore sometimes quirky and imperfect) version and the inhumanly perfect and rapid machine made version. Hand-made crafts are already being presented today as a special valued category. All of these changes could end up teaching us trust and humility, if we could accept them. In the near future, the machines will become better than us at performing more and more tasks. But what we will always have as our advantage, in contrast to the machines, is our capacity for randomness because of our unconscious urges, and the resulting unpredictability which can lead to something unexpected.

Answer: The same way jobs have been replaced since technology began replacing jobs centuries ago: by creating more jobs.Technology replaced the jobs of manually spinning wool into yarn and manually weaving cloth. Those jobs almost entirely disappeared. But technology created more than ten times as many jobs in the mechanical fabric factories.Fiscal conservatism, whatever animosity is behind the use of the term, has nothing to do with jobs and income inequality: it has to do with spending no more than is received in income and maintaining a stable currency.As for addressing growing inequality: it oughtThe same way jobs have been replaced since technology began replacing jobs centuries ago: by creating more jobs.Technology replaced the jobs of manually spinning wool into yarn and manually weaving cloth. Those jobs almost entirely disappeared. But technology created more than ten times as many jobs in the mechanical fabric factories.Fiscal conservatism, whatever animosity is behind the use of the term, has nothing to do with jobs and income inequality: it has to do with spending no more than is received in income and maintaining a stable currency.As for addressing growing inequality: it ought to be addressed by ignoring the vicarious envy of the educated upper-middle class and intellectuals who have decided to worry about it. An individual’s well being is determined by what he is able to consume and enjoy, not the ratio of his monetary income to someone else’s monetary income. Graveyards have perfect income equality.
